page.title: 07ABERDEEN'S COASTAL WATERS
page.content: Looking out to sea one usually spies a variety of vessels lying offshore. Those anchored relativly close to shore are usually supply boats either waiting for berths in the harbour to be vacated or are avoiding berthing charges.Amongthem manoeuvere little trawlers and even smaller salmon-cobbles.Further offshore are larger oil tankers waiting to be called to a rig to load on oil destined normally for Rotterdam.Between shipments the cheapest option is to anchor offshore rather than cruise up and down the North Sea for a week or so. Often on a clear day the gigantic steel structure of an oil rig looms on the horizon.Standing there as a reminder,as if needed,of the present dependence our society has on oil as the major energy source.
